Uppgradera abonnemangetMer åtkomst till de bästa modellerna
Du sade:
I want to make an escape room for my wifes birthday party. I will figure out pussles from things around the apartment but the answering mechanism and story should be a web application. Can you give me a framwork to work from to succeed.
ChatGPT sade:

Creating a web-based escape room game for your wife's birthday is a fantastic idea! Here's a framework to help you succeed, combining an interactive story, puzzle-solving, and an easy-to-use web application:

Step 1: Define the Escape Room Theme and Storyline

The theme and story provide the foundation for your escape room experience. Choose a theme that resonates with your wife’s interests.

Examples:

  • A detective mystery: Solve clues to find a missing treasure.
  • A sci-fi adventure: Escape from a malfunctioning spaceship.
  • A magical quest: Break a spell by solving enchanted puzzles.

Draft a narrative outline:

  1. Introduction: Set the stage and provide a reason for the escape.
  2. Puzzle Sequence: Break the story into chapters, each requiring a puzzle to progress.
  3. Climax/Ending: Create a celebratory or heartfelt resolution.

Step 2: Puzzle Design

Use items from around your apartment for puzzles. Each puzzle can unlock a part of the web application or provide information to progress the story.

Puzzle Ideas:

  • Physical clues: A message in invisible ink that corresponds to a web app code.
  • Combination locks: Use numbers from books, kitchen items, or paintings.
  • Word riddles: A phrase or cipher she decodes to input online.
  • Image matching: Take pictures of items in your home and create a matching game in the app.

Ensure each puzzle:

  • Fits the story.
  • Is challenging but solvable.
  • Leads logically to the next step.

Step 3: Web Application Development

Your web app will tie the puzzles together and serve as the interactive mechanism.

Structure:

  1. Home/Welcome Screen:

    • Brief introduction to the story.
    • A start button.

  2. Puzzle Pages:

    • One page per puzzle with:
      • The current story chapter.
      • Instructions for the puzzle.
      • Input field for answers.
      • Feedback (e.g., “Correct! Proceed to the next challenge.” or “Try again!”).

  3. Final Page:

    • A personalized birthday message.
    • Celebration screen (e.g., confetti, “Congratulations!” animation).

Technical Framework:

  1. Frontend:

    • HTML/CSS: For structure and styling.
    • JavaScript: For interactive elements and puzzle validations.

  2. Backend (optional):

    • Use Node.js, Python (Flask/Django), or PHP to handle more complex logic, track progress, or store data.

  3. Hosting:

    • Free options like GitHub Pages or Netlify.
    • Local hosting on your laptop using tools like XAMPP or ngrok.

  4. Mobile-First Design: Ensure the app works on both desktop and mobile.

Tools to Simplify Development:

  • No-code platforms: Bubble, Glide, or Webflow for faster development.
  • Templates and Libraries: Use Bootstrap for UI, Phaser.js for simple gamification.

Step 4: Test and Prepare

  1. Trial Runs: Test puzzles and the web app to ensure:
    • The puzzles flow logically.
    • The app functions as intended.
  2. Decorate: Use props or lighting to enhance the ambiance of the escape room.
  3. Backup Plan: Keep hints or an override option in case a puzzle stumps her.

Step 5: Execution

  1. Setup: Arrange the physical puzzles and integrate them with the web app.
  2. Immerse: Guide her into the story with an opening scene or dialogue.
  3. Celebrate: Once she completes the escape room, unveil a personalized birthday surprise.

Would you like help designing the puzzles, coding parts of the web app, or anything specific?

Du sade:
I want it to be two teams cooperating to solve a mystery. I will have one team in one room collecting clues and the other team in the other room. They will have to cooperate to solve the mystery.
ChatGPT sade:

This sounds like an incredible setup! Two teams cooperating from different rooms will add a unique layer of excitement and communication to the experience. Here’s how you can organize your cooperative escape room with a web application at its core:

Step 1: Define the Cooperative Storyline

The story should encourage teamwork, with each team having distinct but complementary roles. Here's a cooperative example:

Plot Idea: Two groups are part of a detective agency solving a high-stakes case:

  • Team 1: Forensic Analysts (gathering clues and decoding evidence).
  • Team 2: Field Operatives (navigating the narrative and connecting the dots).
  • They must work together to uncover a plot, stop a villain, or find a treasure.

Step 2: Divide Roles and Tasks

Ensure both teams are essential to the game's progression:

  1. Team 1 (Clue Collectors):

    • Solve puzzles to find hidden clues.
    • Access encrypted messages or symbols that need decoding by Team 2.

  2. Team 2 (Decoders/Strategists):

    • Use the information provided by Team 1.
    • Analyze clues to advance the story or solve the overarching mystery.

Examples of Interdependent Tasks:

  • Team 1 finds a code (e.g., "Red Apple") but doesn’t know how to use it.
  • Team 2 has a cipher key in their room that translates "Red Apple" into coordinates or instructions.
  • Team 2 gets an incomplete map, while Team 1 holds the missing pieces.

Step 3: Puzzle Design

Craft puzzles that require both teams to share and interpret information collaboratively. Use the web app to facilitate cross-team communication and progress tracking.

Puzzle Examples:

  1. Communication Challenge:

    • Team 1 finds a riddle that Team 2 must solve using their resources.
    • Example: "The treasure lies where red meets blue." Team 1 describes a painting or a setup in their room. Team 2 must interpret it with additional info from their screen.

  2. Split Code Puzzle:

    • Split a passphrase or code across both teams.
    • Example: Team 1 sees symbols (e.g., 🟥🟨⬛), and Team 2 has the key that translates them into a word.

  3. Physical to Digital:

    • Team 1 finds physical clues (e.g., numbers on objects) and inputs them into the web app.
    • Team 2 sees the result of that input and uses it to progress further.

  4. Combined Knowledge:

    • Team 1 has a piece of historical text, and Team 2 has a timeline. Together, they piece together a sequence of events.

Step 4: Web Application Design

The web app will act as:

  1. A Story Hub: Delivers the narrative and instructions.
  2. A Puzzle Interface: Allows teams to input their solutions.
  3. A Cross-Team Communication Tool: Facilitates interaction when needed.

Features to Include:

  1. Team-Specific Interfaces:

    • Team 1 and Team 2 each log into their respective dashboards.
    • Each team sees only their puzzles and clues.

  2. Shared Progress Tracker:

    • A shared screen updates when either team solves a puzzle.
    • Example: "The vault door is halfway unlocked."

  3. Hint System:

    • Include a timer and hint button if either team gets stuck.

  4. Chat or Message System:

    • Allow teams to send short messages or pictures through the app.

Technical Framework:

  1. Frontend:

    • Use React or Vue.js for dynamic interfaces.
    • Integrate animations for progress updates.

  2. Backend:

    • Use Node.js or Python Flask/Django to handle user sessions and communication between teams.

  3. Database:

    • Use Firebase or MongoDB to store puzzle states and progress.

  4. Real-Time Features:

    • Use Socket.IO or WebSockets to implement live communication between the two teams.

Step 5: Logistics

  1. Room Setup:

    • Divide items or puzzles so neither room can complete the game alone.
    • Ensure both rooms feel equally immersive and themed.

  2. Technology:

    • Provide laptops, tablets, or phones with access to the web app.
    • Ensure a stable Wi-Fi connection.

  3. Props:

    • Use walkie-talkies, maps, or physical artifacts to complement the digital experience.

Step 6: Test and Refine

  1. Run a trial game with friends to ensure:
    • Puzzles are challenging but solvable.
    • Teams feel balanced in responsibility and contribution.
  2. Adjust based on feedback, ensuring smooth collaboration.

Would you like a basic web app template or help designing specific puzzles?

Du sade:
Yes! The coding mechanism will be fairly simple. I want to use javascript, css and html to build the escape room. The code should just be taking input and check if it is correct as well as play music and narrate the mystery lore.
ChatGPT sade:

Got it! A simple, effective escape room using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript is absolutely doable. Here’s a breakdown of how to structure your project and code, along with an example implementation.

Basic Features to Include

  1. Input Validation:

    • Users enter answers into text fields.
    • JavaScript checks the input against pre-defined correct answers.

  2. Narrative Delivery:

    • Use HTML and CSS to display story elements.
    • Use JavaScript for dynamic storytelling (e.g., changing text or images as puzzles are solved).

  3. Music and Sound Effects:

    • Background music and sound effects triggered at key moments.
    • Use the HTML <audio> element and JavaScript for control.

  4. Team-Specific Pages:

    • Separate HTML files or dynamic sections for each team.
    • A shared progress tracker.

Folder Structure

scss
project/
├── index.html       (Main entry point for Team 1)
├── team2.html       (Entry point for Team 2)
├── style.css        (Stylesheet)
├── script.js        (JavaScript logic)
├── assets/
│   ├── audio/
│   │   ├── background.mp3
│   │   ├── success.mp3
│   │   ├── fail.mp3
│   ├── images/
│   │   ├── clue1.png
│   │   ├── map.png

Code Implementation

index.html (Team 1 Interface)

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Escape Room - Team 1</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <div class="container">
    <h1>Escape Room - Team 1</h1>
    <p id="narrative">You’ve discovered the first clue. Decode it to progress!</p>
    <img src="assets/images/clue1.png" alt="Clue" class="clue-image">
    
    <input type="text" id="answer" placeholder="Enter your answer">
    <button id="submitAnswer">Submit</button>
    <p id="feedback"></p>
  </div>

  <audio id="backgroundMusic" loop>
    <source src="assets/audio/background.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  </audio>
  <audio id="successSound">
    <source src="assets/audio/success.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  </audio>
  <audio id="failSound">
    <source src="assets/audio/fail.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  </audio>

  <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

style.css

css
body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  background-color: #121212;
  color: #fff;
  text-align: center;
  padding: 20px;
}

.container {
  max-width: 600px;
  margin: 0 auto;
  border: 2px solid #444;
  border-radius: 10px;
  padding: 20px;
  background-color: #1e1e1e;
}

.clue-image {
  max-width: 100%;
  margin: 20px 0;
}

input {
  padding: 10px;
  font-size: 16px;
  margin-bottom: 10px;
  width: 80%;
}

button {
  padding: 10px 20px;
  font-size: 16px;
  background-color: #007bff;
  color: white;
  border: none;
  border-radius: 5px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

button:hover {
  background-color: #0056b3;
}

#feedback {
  margin-top: 10px;
  font-size: 18px;
}

script.js

javascript
// Music controls
const backgroundMusic = document.getElementById("backgroundMusic");
const successSound = document.getElementById("successSound");
const failSound = document.getElementById("failSound");
backgroundMusic.play();

// Correct answer for Team 1
const correctAnswer = "sundial";

document.getElementById("submitAnswer").addEventListener("click", function () {
  const userAnswer = document.getElementById("answer").value.trim().toLowerCase();
  const feedback = document.getElementById("feedback");

  if (userAnswer === correctAnswer) {
    feedback.textContent = "Correct! Inform Team 2 to proceed!";
    feedback.style.color = "green";
    successSound.play();
  } else {
    feedback.textContent = "Incorrect! Try again.";
    feedback.style.color = "red";
    failSound.play();
  }
});

team2.html (Team 2 Interface)

This will be similar to index.html but with unique puzzles and a different correct answer.

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Escape Room - Team 2</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <div class="container">
    <h1>Escape Room - Team 2</h1>
    <p id="narrative">Team 1 has sent you a clue. Use it wisely!</p>
    <img src="assets/images/map.png" alt="Map" class="clue-image">
    
    <input type="text" id="answer" placeholder="Enter your answer">
    <button id="submitAnswer">Submit</button>
    <p id="feedback"></p>
  </div>

  <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

How It Works

  1. Narrative Flow: Each team gets a piece of the puzzle to solve independently but must share their answers for mutual progress.
  2. Feedback: Users receive immediate feedback on their answers.
  3. Dynamic Music: Background music and sound effects enhance immersion.

Next Steps

  1. Adjust puzzles for your specific theme.
  2. Add more pages or dynamic sections for new puzzles.
  3. Test with friends or family to ensure flow and difficulty balance.

Would you like assistance customizing puzzles or refining the code further?

Du sade:
How do I run this now from vs code
ChatGPT sade:

Running your escape room project from VS Code is straightforward. Here’s a step-by-step guide:

Step 1: Open the Project in VS Code

  1. Open VS Code.
  2. Go to File > Open Folder and select your project folder (the folder containing your index.html, style.css, and script.js files).

Step 2: Use a Live Server

To view your project in the browser, you'll need to serve the files locally. The best way to do this in VS Code is by using the Live Server extension.

Install Live Server:

  1. Open the Extensions view in VS Code (Ctrl+Shift+X or Cmd+Shift+X on Mac).
  2. Search for Live Server.
  3. Click Install.

Start Live Server:

  1. Right-click on your index.html file in the Explorer sidebar.
  2. Select Open with Live Server.
  3. Your default web browser will open with the project running locally (usually at http://127.0.0.1:5500 or http://localhost:5500).

Step 3: Test Your Project

  1. Interact with the web app in your browser:
    • Test the inputs and outputs.
    • Ensure the music and sound effects work.
  2. Repeat the process for team2.html:
    • Open team2.html in the editor.
    • Right-click and choose Open with Live Server.

Step 4: Troubleshoot Common Issues

  1. Scripts or Styles Not Loading:

    • Check that the file paths for style.css and script.js are correct in your HTML.
    • Make sure assets like images and audio are in the correct assets/ folder.

  2. Live Server Not Installed or Working:

    • If Live Server isn’t an option, you can still view the project by opening index.html directly in your browser (double-click the file). However, some features like audio paths might not work due to browser security policies.

Step 5: (Optional) Enhance Workflow

If you’re planning to iterate on your project, here are tips to speed up development:

  1. Auto-Refresh on Save: Live Server automatically refreshes the browser when you save changes to your code.
  2. Debugging:
    • Open your browser's developer tools (F12 or Cmd+Option+I on Mac).
    • Use the Console tab to view JavaScript errors or logs from your script.js.
  3. Preview CSS Changes in Real-Time: Edit style.css while Live Server is running and see immediate changes.

Would you like help testing the project or adding features now that it's running?

Du sade:
It works
ChatGPT sade:

That's fantastic! 🎉 You're off to a great start. If you need any help refining the puzzles, adding more interactive features, or tweaking the design, feel free to ask. Have fun building your escape room, and good luck with the big day! 😊

Du sade:
Let's revise a little. 1. When I start the live server I want to have a start screen with just a button "begin". 2. At the bottom I would like to have an animated bar showing the progress of both teams. 3. I Would like the theme to be midevil dragon theme. Write a capturing intro to why a dark mage have captured the dragon egg that our two teams are trying to save.
ChatGPT sade:

Let’s revise your escape room with the requested features! Here's how to incorporate the changes:

1. Start Screen with "Begin" Button

We’ll create a start screen that transitions to the first puzzle when the "Begin" button is clicked.

2. Animated Progress Bar

We’ll add a progress bar at the bottom of the screen that visually tracks both teams' progress as they solve puzzles.

3. Medieval Dragon Theme Intro

Here’s a captivating story introduction:

Story Intro:

In the distant kingdom of Eldoria, peace was kept by a magnificent dragon named Auriel. For centuries, Auriel protected the realm with her fiery strength and wisdom. But one fateful night, a dark mage named Malakar, driven by greed and power, cast a sinister spell that shattered the balance. Malakar stole Auriel’s sacred egg, the source of her magic and the hope of Eldoria’s future.

Separated into two guilds—the Seekers and the Scribes—you must work together to outwit Malakar’s puzzles, break his spell, and retrieve the dragon egg before the kingdom falls into eternal darkness.

Updated Code Implementation

index.html (Start Screen + Progress Bar)

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Escape Room - Save the Dragon Egg</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Start Screen -->
  <div id="startScreen" class="screen">
    <h1>Save the Dragon Egg</h1>
    <p>Malakar, the dark mage, has captured Auriel’s sacred dragon egg. Unite the guilds to save Eldoria!</p>
    <button id="beginButton">Begin</button>
  </div>

  <!-- Main Game Screen -->
  <div id="gameScreen" class="screen hidden">
    <h1 id="gameTitle">Save the Dragon Egg - Team 1</h1>
    <p id="narrative">The first puzzle awaits. Solve it to begin your quest!</p>
    <img src="assets/images/clue1.png" alt="Clue" class="clue-image">
    <input type="text" id="answer" placeholder="Enter your answer">
    <button id="submitAnswer">Submit</button>
    <p id="feedback"></p>

    <!-- Progress Bar -->
    <div class="progress-container">
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team1Progress"></div>
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team2Progress"></div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <audio id="backgroundMusic" loop>
    <source src="assets/audio/background.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  </audio>

  <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

style.css (Updated for Theme and Progress Bar)

css
/* General Styles */
body {
  font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif;
  background-color: #1a1a1a;
  color: #fff;
  text-align: center;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

h1 {
  color: #ffcb00;
  font-size: 2.5em;
}

p {
  font-size: 1.2em;
}

button {
  background-color: #6a0dad;
  color: white;
  border: none;
  border-radius: 5px;
  padding: 10px 20px;
  font-size: 16px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

button:hover {
  background-color: #530b8c;
}

.clue-image {
  max-width: 100%;
  margin: 20px 0;
}

/* Hidden Screen */
.hidden {
  display: none;
}

/* Progress Bar */
.progress-container {
  display: flex;
  width: 90%;
  height: 20px;
  margin: 20px auto;
  background-color: #333;
  border: 2px solid #666;
  border-radius: 10px;
  overflow: hidden;
}

.progress-bar {
  flex-grow: 0;
  height: 100%;
  background-color: #ffcb00;
  transition: width 0.5s;
}

#team1Progress {
  background-color: #ff4500;
}

#team2Progress {
  background-color: #008b8b;
}

script.js (Add Start Screen, Progress Bar, and Story Logic)

javascript
// Elements
const startScreen = document.getElementById("startScreen");
const gameScreen = document.getElementById("gameScreen");
const beginButton = document.getElementById("beginButton");
const answerInput = document.getElementById("answer");
const submitButton = document.getElementById("submitAnswer");
const feedback = document.getElementById("feedback");
const team1Progress = document.getElementById("team1Progress");
const team2Progress = document.getElementById("team2Progress");
const backgroundMusic = document.getElementById("backgroundMusic");

// Variables
const correctAnswer = "sundial";
let team1ProgressValue = 0;
let team2ProgressValue = 0;

// Start Screen Logic
beginButton.addEventListener("click", () => {
  startScreen.classList.add("hidden");
  gameScreen.classList.remove("hidden");
  backgroundMusic.play();
});

// Answer Validation Logic
submitButton.addEventListener("click", () => {
  const userAnswer = answerInput.value.trim().toLowerCase();
  if (userAnswer === correctAnswer) {
    feedback.textContent = "Correct! Inform Team 2 to proceed!";
    feedback.style.color = "green";

    // Update Team Progress
    team1ProgressValue += 50; // Increment by 50% for demonstration
    team1Progress.style.width = `${team1ProgressValue}%`;

    // Check if the game is complete
    if (team1ProgressValue >= 100 && team2ProgressValue >= 100) {
      feedback.textContent = "Congratulations! The dragon egg is saved!";
    }
  } else {
    feedback.textContent = "Incorrect! Try again.";
    feedback.style.color = "red";
  }
});

// Example function to simulate Team 2's progress (use real events in the future)
setInterval(() => {
  if (team2ProgressValue < 100) {
    team2ProgressValue += 25; // Simulated progress
    team2Progress.style.width = `${team2ProgressValue}%`;
  }
}, 5000); // Increment every 5 seconds

How It Works

  1. Start Screen: The user sees the introduction and clicks "Begin" to start the game.
  2. Game Screen: The main game appears with a narrative, a puzzle input, and a shared progress bar.
  3. Progress Bar:
    • Updates dynamically as teams solve puzzles.
    • The setInterval function simulates Team 2’s progress for now. You can replace this with real-time logic once implemented.

Next Steps

  1. Replace the simulated Team 2 progress with actual events when their puzzles are implemented.
  2. Add more puzzles with increasing complexity and narrative depth.
  3. Customize the progress bar increments based on your puzzle designs.

Would you like help refining the puzzles or adding additional features?

Du sade:
index.html and team2.html need to communicate to share their status
ChatGPT sade:

To allow communication between index.html (Team 1) and team2.html (Team 2), we can use a simple serverless approach leveraging the browser's localStorage or sessionStorage APIs. These APIs store data locally and can be accessed by both HTML files running on the same domain. Here’s how to implement it:

Implementation Plan

  1. Shared State via localStorage: Store the progress of both teams in localStorage. Both HTML files can read and update this shared state.
  2. Update the Progress Bar Dynamically: Each page will regularly check the progress from localStorage and update its progress bar.
  3. Real-Time Synchronization: Use setInterval to periodically check for changes in progress.

Updated Code for Communication

index.html (Team 1 Page)

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Escape Room - Save the Dragon Egg</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Game Screen -->
  <div id="gameScreen" class="screen">
    <h1>Save the Dragon Egg - Team 1</h1>
    <p id="narrative">The first puzzle awaits. Solve it to begin your quest!</p>
    <img src="assets/images/clue1.png" alt="Clue" class="clue-image">
    <input type="text" id="answer" placeholder="Enter your answer">
    <button id="submitAnswer">Submit</button>
    <p id="feedback"></p>

    <!-- Progress Bar -->
    <div class="progress-container">
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team1Progress"></div>
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team2Progress"></div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

team2.html (Team 2 Page)

This file is similar to index.html but represents Team 2's side.

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Escape Room - Save the Dragon Egg</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Game Screen -->
  <div id="gameScreen" class="screen">
    <h1>Save the Dragon Egg - Team 2</h1>
    <p id="narrative">The first puzzle awaits. Solve it to begin your quest!</p>
    <img src="assets/images/clue2.png" alt="Clue" class="clue-image">
    <input type="text" id="answer" placeholder="Enter your answer">
    <button id="submitAnswer">Submit</button>
    <p id="feedback"></p>

    <!-- Progress Bar -->
    <div class="progress-container">
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team1Progress"></div>
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team2Progress"></div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

script.js (Shared Logic for Both Pages)

This JavaScript file will manage progress and communication via localStorage.

javascript
// Elements
const answerInput = document.getElementById("answer");
const submitButton = document.getElementById("submitAnswer");
const feedback = document.getElementById("feedback");
const team1Progress = document.getElementById("team1Progress");
const team2Progress = document.getElementById("team2Progress");

// Correct answers for demonstration
const correctAnswer = location.pathname.includes("team2.html") ? "fireball" : "sundial";

// Update progress bar function
function updateProgressBars() {
  const progress = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("progress")) || { team1: 0, team2: 0 };
  team1Progress.style.width = `${progress.team1}%`;
  team2Progress.style.width = `${progress.team2}%`;
}

// Submit answer
submitButton.addEventListener("click", () => {
  const userAnswer = answerInput.value.trim().toLowerCase();
  const progress = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("progress")) || { team1: 0, team2: 0 };

  if (userAnswer === correctAnswer) {
    feedback.textContent = "Correct! Inform the other team to proceed!";
    feedback.style.color = "green";

    if (location.pathname.includes("team2.html")) {
      progress.team2 += 50; // Increment Team 2's progress
    } else {
      progress.team1 += 50; // Increment Team 1's progress
    }

    // Update shared progress in localStorage
    localStorage.setItem("progress", JSON.stringify(progress));
    updateProgressBars();

    // Check if the game is complete
    if (progress.team1 >= 100 && progress.team2 >= 100) {
      feedback.textContent = "Congratulations! The dragon egg is saved!";
    }
  } else {
    feedback.textContent = "Incorrect! Try again.";
    feedback.style.color = "red";
  }
});

// Synchronize progress between pages
setInterval(updateProgressBars, 1000); // Check every second

// Initialize progress bars on page load
updateProgressBars();

How It Works

  1. Shared Progress via localStorage:

    • Each team’s page updates its progress in localStorage.
    • Progress is stored as a JSON object: { team1: 50, team2: 25 }.

  2. Synchronization:

    • Both pages use setInterval to check for updates in localStorage every second and adjust their progress bars accordingly.

  3. Unique Correct Answers:

    • Each page checks the URL (location.pathname) to load the correct answer for that team’s puzzle.

  4. Game Completion:

    • When both teams reach 100% progress, a congratulatory message is displayed.

Next Steps

  1. Testing:

    • Open index.html and team2.html in separate browser tabs or devices.
    • Verify that progress updates on both pages when one team submits a correct answer.

  2. Enhancements:

    • Add more puzzles and increment progress accordingly.
    • Use more sophisticated animations for the progress bars.

Let me know if you’d like help testing or expanding this further! 😊

Du sade:
What happend to my begin screen?
ChatGPT sade:

It looks like the "Begin" screen functionality was removed in the revised code for simplicity while focusing on team communication. Let me integrate the Begin Screen back into the workflow, ensuring it transitions properly to the puzzle screens for both index.html and team2.html.

Updated Code with the Begin Screen

index.html

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Escape Room - Save the Dragon Egg</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Start Screen -->
  <div id="startScreen" class="screen">
    <h1>Save the Dragon Egg</h1>
    <p>Malakar, the dark mage, has captured Auriel’s sacred dragon egg. Unite the guilds to save Eldoria!</p>
    <button id="beginButton">Begin</button>
  </div>

  <!-- Game Screen -->
  <div id="gameScreen" class="screen hidden">
    <h1>Save the Dragon Egg - Team 1</h1>
    <p id="narrative">The first puzzle awaits. Solve it to begin your quest!</p>
    <img src="assets/images/clue1.png" alt="Clue" class="clue-image">
    <input type="text" id="answer" placeholder="Enter your answer">
    <button id="submitAnswer">Submit</button>
    <p id="feedback"></p>

    <!-- Progress Bar -->
    <div class="progress-container">
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team1Progress"></div>
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team2Progress"></div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

team2.html

Identical to index.html but with appropriate team-specific labels.

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Escape Room - Save the Dragon Egg</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Start Screen -->
  <div id="startScreen" class="screen">
    <h1>Save the Dragon Egg</h1>
    <p>Malakar, the dark mage, has captured Auriel’s sacred dragon egg. Unite the guilds to save Eldoria!</p>
    <button id="beginButton">Begin</button>
  </div>

  <!-- Game Screen -->
  <div id="gameScreen" class="screen hidden">
    <h1>Save the Dragon Egg - Team 2</h1>
    <p id="narrative">The first puzzle awaits. Solve it to begin your quest!</p>
    <img src="assets/images/clue2.png" alt="Clue" class="clue-image">
    <input type="text" id="answer" placeholder="Enter your answer">
    <button id="submitAnswer">Submit</button>
    <p id="feedback"></p>

    <!-- Progress Bar -->
    <div class="progress-container">
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team1Progress"></div>
      <div class="progress-bar" id="team2Progress"></div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

script.js (with Begin Screen Functionality)

javascript
// Elements
const startScreen = document.getElementById("startScreen");
const gameScreen = document.getElementById("gameScreen");
const beginButton = document.getElementById("beginButton");
const answerInput = document.getElementById("answer");
const submitButton = document.getElementById("submitAnswer");
const feedback = document.getElementById("feedback");
const team1Progress = document.getElementById("team1Progress");
const team2Progress = document.getElementById("team2Progress");

// Correct answers for demonstration
const correctAnswer = location.pathname.includes("team2.html") ? "fireball" : "sundial";

// Begin Button Logic
beginButton.addEventListener("click", () => {
  startScreen.classList.add("hidden");
  gameScreen.classList.remove("hidden");
});

// Update progress bar function
function updateProgressBars() {
  const progress = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("progress")) || { team1: 0, team2: 0 };
  team1Progress.style.width = `${progress.team1}%`;
  team2Progress.style.width = `${progress.team2}%`;
}

// Submit answer
submitButton.addEventListener("click", () => {
  const userAnswer = answerInput.value.trim().toLowerCase();
  const progress = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("progress")) || { team1: 0, team2: 0 };

  if (userAnswer === correctAnswer) {
    feedback.textContent = "Correct! Inform the other team to proceed!";
    feedback.style.color = "green";

    if (location.pathname.includes("team2.html")) {
      progress.team2 += 50; // Increment Team 2's progress
    } else {
      progress.team1 += 50; // Increment Team 1's progress
    }

    // Update shared progress in localStorage
    localStorage.setItem("progress", JSON.stringify(progress));
    updateProgressBars();

    // Check if the game is complete
    if (progress.team1 >= 100 && progress.team2 >= 100) {
      feedback.textContent = "Congratulations! The dragon egg is saved!";
    }
  } else {
    feedback.textContent = "Incorrect! Try again.";
    feedback.style.color = "red";
  }
});

// Synchronize progress between pages
setInterval(updateProgressBars, 1000); // Check every second

// Initialize progress bars on page load
updateProgressBars();

How It Works

  1. Begin Screen:

    • Both index.html and team2.html now start with a begin screen.
    • Clicking the "Begin" button transitions to the main game.

  2. Progress Bar Sync:

    • Progress is still shared using localStorage and updated dynamically.

  3. Story & Team Separation:

    • Each team gets its unique title, narrative, and answer logic based on the URL.

Would you like to test it or add another feature? 😊

ChatGPT sade:
